newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds close much weaker but outperform U.S..
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds close much weaker but outperform U.S..

text.p: Canadian bonds closed much weaker in an abbreviated session on Thursday, dropping with U.S. Treasuries on the release of stronger-than-expected U.S. data, analysts said.
At the same time, Canadian bonds sharply outperformed U.S. Treasuries, with the spread between Canadian and U.S. long bonds falling to its lowest level in recent history.

"The basic story is we've had a 25-basis-point Fed tightening, and all evidence since the tightening is supporting yet another tightening in May," said Andrew Pyle, head of fixed income research with ABN AMRO Bank Canada.

Canada's 30-year benchmark bond fell C$0.90 to C$108.38 to yield 7.278 percent, its lowest level since January. The U.S. 30-year bond fell 1 - 8/32 to yield 7.09 percent. The spread between the two bonds narrowed to 19 basis points from 23 basis points, its lowest level so far this decade.
Both Canadian and U.S. bonds weakened this morning following a U.S. report that sales of existing or previously occupied homes rose 9.0 percent in February from January, well above expectations.
Other reports on U.S. help wanted advertising and jobless claims confirmed U.S. economic growth is robust.

"Obviously, the Canadian bonds have been influenced by the U.S.," said David Ebata, a Canadian market analyst with Technical Data. "The U.S. market has already discounted another quarter percent by June."
Analysts cautioned Canada's bond market outperformance may be due to thin volumes and may not be sustainable.

"It's a pretty quiet market so I don't think you can necessarily say that those levels are going to hold. I think we'll have to see midweek of next week," said Mary Jane Yule, a fixed-income portfolio manager with Jones Heward Investment Counsel.
Canadian markets will be closed tomorrow for Good Friday but trading will resume on Monday.

Analysts said an economic report that Canada's real gross domestic product rose 0.6 percent in January had little impact on Canadian bond prices. A Reuters survey of economists had forecast real GDP to rise 0.4 percent in January.
In other prices, the Government of Canada's 7.0 percent bond due 2006 fell C$0.57 to C$102.25 to yield 6.678 percent. The U.S. bond fell 28/32 to yield 6.91 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds widened to 23 basis points from from 18 basis points on Wednesday.
The three-month cash T-bill yielded 3.18 percent against its U.S. equivalent which yielded 5.37 percent.
